title: Ezekiel Chapter 32 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 32 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 32 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 32.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 32:2, to whom does the LORD command Ezekiel to take up a lamentation?
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh king of Egypt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:2 commands to take up a lamentation for Pharaoh king of Egypt.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 32:3, what will the LORD spread out over Pharaoh?
questions.correctAnswer: A net
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:3 states the LORD will spread out a net over Pharaoh with a company of many people.

questions.question: What will the LORD cause to remain upon Pharaoh, as mentioned in Ezekiel 32:4?
options: All the fowls of the heaven
questions.correctAnswer: All the fowls of the heaven
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:4 mentions the LORD will cause all the fowls of heaven to remain upon Pharaoh.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 32:7 describes the sun being covered with a cloud during Pharaoh's fall.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:7 states the sun will be covered with a cloud when Pharaoh is put out.

questions.question: Who does Ezekiel say will bring destruction upon Pharaoh according to Ezekiel 32:11?
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:11 states the sword of the king of Babylon shall come upon Pharaoh.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Ezekiel 32:15: 'When I shall make the land of Egypt ________, then shall they know that I am the LORD.'
questions.correctAnswer: desolate
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:15 says the land of Egypt will be made desolate before they know the LORD.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 32:16, who shall lament over Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: The daughters of the nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:16 states the daughters of the nations shall lament Egypt.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 32:18 commands to wail for the multitude of Babylon.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:18 commands to wail for the multitude of Egypt, not Babylon.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 32:22, which nation is mentioned as being slain and lying in graves?
questions.correctAnswer: Asshur
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:22 mentions Asshur and all her company as slain and lying in graves.

questions.question: Who is said to lie uncircumcised with the slain according to Ezekiel 32:27?
options: The mighty that are fallen of the uncircumcised
questions.correctAnswer: The mighty that are fallen of the uncircumcised
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:27 says the mighty fallen of the uncircumcised lie with their weapons of war.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 32:31 says Pharaoh will be comforted over all his multitude slain by the sword.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:31 states Pharaoh shall be comforted over all his multitude slain by the sword.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 32:14, how will the LORD make the rivers run?
questions.correctAnswer: Like oil
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:14 says the LORD will make the rivers run like oil.

questions.question: Which group is NOT mentioned among those lying slain in the nether parts of the earth in Ezekiel 32?
questions.correctAnswer: The daughters of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32 mentions Zidonians, princes of the north, and Edom but not daughters of Israel among the slain.

questions.question: What does the LORD say will fill the valleys according to Ezekiel 32:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy height
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:5 says the LORD will lay Pharaoh's flesh on the mountains and fill the valleys with his height.

questions.question: Complete the phrase from Ezekiel 32:6: 'I will also water with thy blood the land wherein thou ______, even to the mountains.'
questions.correctAnswer: swimmest
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:6 uses the phrase 'the land wherein thou swimmest'.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 32 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 32 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Ezekiel 32, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God's sovereign plan?
options: God uses nations and circumstances to accomplish His purposes
Trials are always a sign of God’s rejection
We should avoid all difficulties to please God
God’s plans are easily understood by everyone
questions.correctAnswer: God uses nations and circumstances to accomplish His purposes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:3-12 shows how God declares judgment on Egypt through the king of Babylon, illustrating that God sovereignly uses nations and events to fulfill His will. This teaches trust in God's sovereign plan even in difficult times.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 32 teach about humility in the face of pride and power?
options: Pride leads to downfall and destruction by God’s hand
Pride is rewarded with lasting honor
Humility is unnecessary when one is strong
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to downfall and destruction by God’s hand
questions.explanation: Verses 2, 10, and 12 describe Pharaoh as a proud lion and whale who will be humbled and destroyed. This shows that pride precedes judgment, teaching believers humility before God.

questions.question: A believer struggles with anger toward an enemy. Based on Ezekiel 32, what biblical principle can encourage forgiveness and reconciliation?
options: God’s judgment is perfect and final, so we should leave vengeance to Him
Holding grudges is a way to honor God
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment is perfect and final, so we should leave vengeance to Him
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:10-12 shows God’s righteous judgment on enemies like Egypt, reminding believers to trust God’s justice rather than seeking revenge themselves, encouraging forgiveness.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 32 teach about perseverance through trials and trusting God's timing?
options: God’s timing for judgment and restoration is perfect and assured
We should give up when trials come
Trials mean God has abandoned us
questions.correctAnswer: God’s timing for judgment and restoration is perfect and assured
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:15-16 and 31-32 reveal God’s sure judgment on Egypt and His purposeful timing, teaching believers to persevere in faith, trusting God’s perfect timing.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 32 encourage believers in the practice of prayer during hardship?
options: Prayer is essential to seek God’s mercy and guidance in times of distress
Prayer is only for joyful times
Hardships mean God does not hear prayers
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is essential to seek God’s mercy and guidance in times of distress
questions.explanation: The lamentation tone in Ezekiel 32:1-2 and the call to lament in verses 16-18 show the importance of crying out to God in prayer during trials, teaching reliance on Him.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment amid loss. What biblical truth from Ezekiel 32 can encourage contentment and gratitude?
options: Recognizing God’s sovereignty helps us be content even in loss
Loss means God is angry and not to be trusted
questions.correctAnswer: Recognizing God’s sovereignty helps us be content even in loss
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:15-16 and 32 emphasize God’s control over nations and outcomes, teaching believers to trust and be grateful for His sovereign care despite losses.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 32 instruct us on honesty and integrity when facing challenges in work or daily life?
options: We should remain faithful and trust God’s justice even when circumstances are difficult
Dishonesty is acceptable if it helps us survive
Integrity is not important during trials
We should avoid responsibility in hard times
questions.correctAnswer: We should remain faithful and trust God’s justice even when circumstances are difficult
questions.explanation: Through the imagery of judgment and downfall in Ezekiel 32:11-14, believers learn to maintain integrity and trust in God’s just handling of situations rather than resorting to dishonesty.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 32 teaches that God’s judgment results in complete destruction and despair without hope for restoration.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: While Ezekiel 32 details harsh judgment on Egypt (verses 12-15), the context of Ezekiel’s prophecies includes eventual restoration, showing God’s justice is balanced with mercy and hope.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 32, believers should fear earthly powers more than God’s authority.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:10-11 highlights that even mighty kings and nations tremble before God’s sword, teaching that God’s authority is supreme over all earthly powers.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 32 compares Pharaoh to a _____ among the nations and a _____ in the seas.
questions.correctAnswer: young lion, whale
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:2 describes Pharaoh as 'a young lion of the nations' and 'a whale in the seas,' illustrating his power and pride before judgment.

questions.question: How does the lamentation over Egypt in Ezekiel 32 teach us about empathy and intercession for others?
options: Believers should mourn and pray for those facing judgment, showing compassion
We should rejoice over others’ misfortunes
Intercession is only for fellow believers
Empathy is not needed during God’s judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should mourn and pray for those facing judgment, showing compassion
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:16-18 calls for lamentation for Egypt and the nations, encouraging believers to respond with compassion and intercession for others, even in judgment.

questions.question: What practical lesson about stewardship and responsibility can be drawn from Ezekiel 32’s description of Egypt’s downfall?
options: Misusing power and resources leads to ruin, so we must steward them wisely
We can use resources selfishly without consequences
Stewardship is unrelated to God’s judgment
Only material wealth matters in stewardship
questions.correctAnswer: Misusing power and resources leads to ruin, so we must steward them wisely
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:5-6 shows how Egypt’s pride and misuse lead to destruction, teaching believers to manage resources with integrity and responsibility.

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 32, how should believers approach evangelism and sharing the gospel in a world full of spiritual darkness?
options: Believers should bring light and hope where darkness covers the land
Evangelism is unnecessary because darkness is too strong
Only pastors should share the gospel
People will not listen, so we should not try
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should bring light and hope where darkness covers the land
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:7-8 describes darkness covering the heavens and the land, symbolizing judgment; believers are called to be light in such darkness through gospel witness.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 32 encourage believers to maintain hope and faithfulness in family and marriage amid trials?
options: Trusting God’s justice and mercy helps families endure hardships together
Trials mean God is displeased with the family
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God’s justice and mercy helps families endure hardships together
questions.explanation: The lament and judgments in Ezekiel 32:15-16 demonstrate hardship, but the overall message encourages faithfulness and trust in God’s justice and mercy for families to persevere.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and contentment can be learned from the fate of the mighty nations mentioned in Ezekiel 32?
options: Even the strongest fall and must bear shame, teaching humility and contentment
Humility is unnecessary for the powerful
questions.correctAnswer: Even the strongest fall and must bear shame, teaching humility and contentment
questions.explanation: Verses 26-30 detail the fall of powerful nations and princes who lie slain and uncircumcised, showing that all must humble themselves before God and find contentment beyond power.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 32 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 32.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 32:2, Pharaoh is compared to which two creatures to describe his power and influence?
options: A young lion and a whale
questions.correctAnswer: A young lion and a whale
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:2 explicitly compares Pharaoh to a young lion of the nations and a whale in the seas, emphasizing his might and dominion.

questions.question: What is the symbolic meaning of God spreading out His net over Pharaoh in Ezekiel 32:3?
options: Capturing and destroying Pharaoh and his forces
questions.correctAnswer: Capturing and destroying Pharaoh and his forces
questions.explanation: The net metaphor in Ezekiel 32:3 signifies God's intent to capture Pharaoh and his multitude, indicating impending judgment and destruction.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 32:7-8, what cosmic signs accompany Pharaoh’s downfall?
options: Darkening of stars, sun, and moon
questions.correctAnswer: Darkening of stars, sun, and moon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:7-8 describe how God will cover the heavens, darken the stars, cover the sun with a cloud, and cause the moon not to give light as signs of judgment.

questions.question: Ezekiel 32:11 identifies which king as the one whose sword will come upon Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:11 specifically states that the sword of the king of Babylon shall come upon Egypt, indicating Babylon as the agent of divine judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 32:14 states, 'Then will I make their waters deep, and cause their rivers to run like ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: oil
questions.explanation: The simile in Ezekiel 32:14 uses 'oil' to describe the deep, sluggish rivers after Egypt’s desolation, symbolizing the cessation of life-giving water flow.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the lamentation Ezekiel is commanded to take up for Pharaoh in Ezekiel 32:2?
options: To mourn the fall of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: To mourn the fall of Egypt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:2 commands a lamentation for Pharaoh, signifying a mourning over Egypt’s impending downfall and destruction.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 32 depicts Pharaoh’s demise as an isolated event without impact on other nations.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:9-10 shows that the destruction of Egypt will cause fear and amazement among many nations and kings, indicating a broad impact.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 32:15, what will Egypt know after its land is made desolate?
options: That the gods of Egypt prevail
questions.correctAnswer: That the LORD is God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:15 states that after Egypt’s desolation, its people shall know that the LORD is the God who executed judgment.

questions.question: Which of the following nations is NOT mentioned among those lying with the uncircumcised dead in the nether parts of the earth (Ezekiel 32:22-30)?
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:22-30 lists Asshur, Elam, Meshech, Tubal, Edom, and others but does not mention Israel among the nations lying with the uncircumcised dead.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Ezekiel 32 to convey the fall of Egypt through the repeated imagery of beasts, rivers, darkness, and the net?
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolism
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32 employs symbolism extensively—beasts represent power, rivers symbolize life and dominion, darkness reflects judgment, and the net signifies capture and destruction.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 32:27, what is said about the weapons of the mighty fallen uncircumcised?
options: Their swords are laid under their heads
questions.correctAnswer: Their swords are laid under their heads
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:27 states that the mighty who have fallen uncircumcised have laid their swords under their heads, symbolizing their death and final rest.

questions.question: Ezekiel 32:16 mentions a lamentation involving the 'daughters of the nations.' What does this phrase likely represent in the ancient Near Eastern context?
questions.correctAnswer: Foreign nations mourning Egypt
questions.explanation: The 'daughters of the nations' in Ezekiel 32:16 often denotes neighboring or foreign nations, here mourning the fall of Egypt, typical of ancient Near Eastern poetic personification.

questions.question: Which theme in Ezekiel 32 is developed across Scripture, particularly in prophetic books like Isaiah and Jeremiah?
options: The establishment of a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment on proud nations
questions.explanation: The theme of divine judgment on proud nations seen in Ezekiel 32 parallels prophetic themes in Isaiah and Jeremiah, emphasizing God's sovereignty over all kingdoms.

questions.question: How does the historical context of Egypt's power during Ezekiel's time influence the imagery in Ezekiel 32?
options: Egypt’s status as a major regional power and rival to Babylon
Egypt as a minor localized kingdom
Egypt’s role as a religious sanctuary only
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt’s status as a major regional power and rival to Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32 reflects Egypt’s political and military significance as a powerful rival to Babylon during the early 6th century BCE, which contextualizes the judgment pronounced against Pharaoh.

questions.question: True or False: The lamentation for Egypt in Ezekiel 32 includes a foreshadowing of the ultimate futility of human might against God's will.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter foreshadows that despite Egypt’s might and terror (Ezekiel 32:26-27), all will fall and be humbled by God’s sovereign judgment, showing human power’s futility.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 32 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 32 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 32:2, Pharaoh is compared to which two creatures, symbolizing his pride and dominion?
options: A young lion and a whale
questions.correctAnswer: A young lion and a whale
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:2 describes Pharaoh as a young lion of the nations and a whale in the seas, symbolizing his strength and dominion. This imagery reflects God's judgment on pride and power, consistent with passages like Daniel 7:4 (lion symbolism), Jonah 1:17 (whale/sea creature), and Revelation 13:2 (beast imagery).

questions.question: What method does God say He will use to bring Pharaoh down according to Ezekiel 32:3?
questions.correctAnswer: A net spread over him
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:3 states God will spread out His net over Pharaoh with many people to bring him up in the net, symbolizing inevitable judgment. Similar imagery of God’s judgment as a net is found in Jeremiah 16:16 and Matthew 13:47-50, emphasizing divine sovereignty over nations.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 32:7-8, what cosmic signs will accompany Pharaoh’s downfall?
options: Darkened stars, sun covered by cloud, and moon without light
questions.correctAnswer: Darkened stars, sun covered by cloud, and moon without light
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 describe the heavens being darkened, stars made dark, sun covered by a cloud, and moon not giving light, symbolizing divine judgment affecting creation. This mirrors Joel 2:10, Amos 8:9, and Mark 13:24-25, indicating eschatological signs of God's intervention.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Ezekiel 32:15, God says when He makes the land of Egypt desolate, the people shall know that ______.
questions.correctAnswer: I am the LORD
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:15 concludes with the declaration that the desolation of Egypt will reveal God's sovereignty: 'then shall they know that I am the LORD.' This aligns with Exodus 9:16, Isaiah 45:6, and John 17:3, emphasizing God's revelation through judgment.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 32:11 identify as the instrument of Pharaoh’s destruction?
options: The sword of the king of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The sword of the king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:11 clearly states that the sword of the king of Babylon will come upon Pharaoh, indicating God's use of Babylon as an instrument of judgment. This is consistent with Isaiah 10:5-6 and Jeremiah 51:20-23, where God raises nations to accomplish His purposes.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 32:6, what will happen to the rivers where Pharaoh swam?
options: They will be watered with his blood
They will become sweet and pure
questions.correctAnswer: They will be watered with his blood
questions.explanation: Verse 6 says God will water the land where Pharaoh swam with his blood, meaning his violent death will pollute the land. This imagery echoes Revelation 16:3 (rivers turning to blood) and Psalm 78:62, demonstrating the consequences of sin and judgment.

questions.question: Which nations or peoples are described in Ezekiel 32:22-30 as being among the slain laid in the pit with Egypt?
options: Asshur, Elam, Meshech, Tubal, Edom, princes of the north, and Zidonians
Babylon, Moab, Ammon, Philistines, and Canaanites
Israel, Judah, Moab, Edom, and Philistia
Greece, Rome, Persia, Egypt, and Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Asshur, Elam, Meshech, Tubal, Edom, princes of the north, and Zidonians
questions.explanation: Verses 22-30 list these specific nations as lying slain in the pit alongside Egypt, reflecting the theme of God's judgment on proud nations. This corresponds to Ezekiel 38:2-6 and Isaiah 13-14, where God pronounces judgment on these historical enemies.

questions.question: What is the significance of Pharaoh being laid ‘in the midst of the uncircumcised’ according to Ezekiel 32:19 and surrounding verses?
options: It signifies shame and exclusion from God's covenant people
It signifies honor among the nations
It signifies a new covenant with God
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies shame and exclusion from God's covenant people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 32:19 and following verses emphasize Pharaoh lying with the uncircumcised, symbolizing exclusion from the covenant community and disgrace. This theme is consistent with Genesis 17:10-14 (circumcision as covenant sign), Romans 2:28-29, and Deuteronomy 10:16.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 32:14, what metaphor is used to describe the rivers after God’s judgment on Egypt?
options: They will dry up like dust
They will be filled with fire
questions.correctAnswer: They will run like oil
questions.explanation: Verse 14 says God will make the waters deep and cause the rivers to run like oil, symbolizing a heavy, stagnant, or oppressive state. This metaphor signifies judgment and desolation, resonating with Isaiah 1:6 and Psalm 65:9 where oil symbolizes abundance or heaviness.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 32:10 describe the reaction of other nations and kings to the fall of Egypt?
options: They shall be horribly afraid and tremble for their lives
They shall unite to fight Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be horribly afraid and tremble for their lives
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states that many people will be amazed and their kings will be terribly afraid, trembling at the fall of Egypt, revealing the terror of God's judgment. This connects to Psalm 2:1-4 and Revelation 6:15-17, showing fear before divine justice.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 32:13, what will happen to the beasts of Egypt after the judgment?
options: They will be destroyed and no longer troubled by man
They will multiply and inhabit the land
They will flee to other nations
questions.correctAnswer: They will be destroyed and no longer troubled by man
questions.explanation: Verse 13 declares that all the beasts beside the great waters will be destroyed and no longer troubled by humans, symbolizing ecological desolation. This aligns with Isaiah 34:11-15 and Jeremiah 4:23-26, indicating total judgment affecting all creation.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the lamentation for Egypt in Ezekiel 32:16-16 and 18-32?
options: It demonstrates God's righteous judgment and the inevitability of death for nations opposing Him
It shows God’s favor on Egypt
It predicts a future restoration without judgment
It encourages Egyptian worship of Yahweh
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates God's righteous judgment and the inevitability of death for nations opposing Him
questions.explanation: The lamentation highlights the certainty of God's judgment on proud nations like Egypt, emphasizing divine holiness and justice. This theme is consistent with Romans 1:18-20, Isaiah 13, and Habakkuk 1, illustrating God's sovereignty and wrath against sin.

questions.question: Ezekiel 32:4-5 describes that God will cause all the fowls of heaven and beasts of the earth to remain upon Pharaoh’s dead body. What does this signify about God's judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Complete defeat and dishonor
questions.explanation: Verses 4-5 portray God leaving Pharaoh's body exposed to scavengers, symbolizing utter defeat and disgrace. This imagery is also found in Deuteronomy 28:26, 2 Samuel 21:10, and Ezekiel 39:17-20, emphasizing the consequences of rebellion against God.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 32:12, what will happen to the 'pomp of Egypt' and its multitude?
options: They shall be spoiled and destroyed
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be spoiled and destroyed
questions.explanation: Verse 12 declares that the multitude and pomp of Egypt will be spoiled and destroyed, signifying the totality of God's judgment against their pride. This is consistent with Nahum 3:1-7, Isaiah 19:1, and Jeremiah 46:25, where Egypt's downfall is prophesied.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 32:31-32, how will Pharaoh react when he sees the multitudes slain by the sword?
options: He will be comforted over all his multitude
questions.correctAnswer: He will be comforted over all his multitude
questions.explanation: Verses 31-32 state Pharaoh shall see the slain multitude and be comforted, likely in a vain or ironic sense, reflecting the futility of earthly power. This theme of ironic comfort appears in Job 21:7 and Habakkuk 1:13, showing human pride’s emptiness before God.
